awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to minimize landfilled waste disposal and produce clean and renewable solid fuel.  The main objective of the project is to gain insight into customer needs and to determine if there is a value proposition for this technology.  Waste is a feedstock that is difficult to handle and has large inconsistencies with high chlorine content. The team has developed a heat treatment that addresses these issues, producing a torrefied fuel product that will benefit energy intensive companies (cement kilns, metallurgy, power, etc.), encouraging them to use renewable energy and reduce costs.  Society will benefit from this project through reduced landfilling, which will preserve the land from future landfilling, reduce pollution by the toxic leachates, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and turn waste into a resource, thus supporting the circular economy. 

This I-Corps project will reveal customer needs and pain points in the area of solid fuel combustion and help to determine if torrefied waste can be considered as a solid fuel used in small-to-medium size power plants.  As part of the customer discovery process, problems in using waste for energy applications such as difficulty in handling, difficulty in transport, large inconsistencies, high chlorine content, and severe corrosion and emissions will be explored. The team has developed a torrefaction system that addresses these hindrances with a series of processes, including downsizing, melting, pyrolization, and pelletization which reduces chlorine and sulfur. This torrefied product is pellet-shaped with high uniformity, high density, high heat content, high consistency, and high durability.  The pellets are low in chlorine content, grindable, safe to store, safe to ship, and low in cost.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For the seven-week time, our team (#2147, Stas Zinchik - Entrepreneur Lead, Ezra Bar-Ziv - Technical Lead, and Ted Hansen - Industrial Mentor) conducted over 200 interviews (116 during the cohort) with a versatile and diverse group of experts from the packaging, waste, and energy sectors. Our journey started with the notion that the Waste Torrefaction Technology and the product properties are the most important part in the commercialization effort. However, we have quickly learned that this is not the case and we shifted our focus to individuals in key positions. With the I-CORPS teaching teams’ guidance, we conducted all the interviews without mentioning the technology or product. We asked questions about where the pain points in the operation are and how can those problems be solved. Specifically, how will the sustainability professional plans to achieve the ultimate sustainability goals their companies have committed to.

We have learned and adopted our value proposition, from focusing on the product benefits to the problem this technology and product can solve. Further, we learnt that the main driving force for the adaptation of fuel is not the utilities (mainly coal) but the packaging companies that have no solution for non-recyclable plastic & paper mix. With this perception in mind, we continued our pursuit and were able to discover that the main reason that drives the change in the market. The end user for any packaging is more environmentally aware than ever before and is basing their purchasing decision on the how sustainable the packaging manufacturing company is.

At the end of the project Team #2147 decided to continue with the customer discovery activities and implement the learning of the course. The team chose to open a start-up company “ZiTechnologies, Inc”. The company successfully applied for an NSF-STTR award. Furthermore, the company is in advanced negotiations with two potential customers willing to commit to a Commercial Demonstration Unit. The broader impact of the implementation of the technology and the use of the product is the reduction in landfill usage. Waste landfill disposal requires huge land areas, produce toxic leachates, and is not sustainable. As an alternative, we proposed a safe and sustainable way to turn waste into a resource and does not require tax increase. The organic portion of the waste, when combusted, can be considered renewable, hence helping reduce greenhouse gases from fossil-fuels. An LCA study found that implementing the Waste Torrefaction Technology can reduce the GHG emission (CO2eq) by up to 80% when compared to landfill disposal (which generates methane) and energy production from coal.

Modified by: Ezra Bar Ziv
